Sequence Information.Peptide Name: Alarin (neuropeptide; natural AMPs; human, primates, mammals, animals; BBMm)

Literature Information.Literature: Discovery: Originally discovered as neuropeptide in 2006 (Santic R et al 2006). It was termed alarin because of the N-terminal alanine and the C-terminal serine.Activity: In 2013, this peptide was demonstrated to have antimicrobial activity as well. Diffusion assay: Active against Gram-negative E. coli ML-35 (3 mm at 100 pmol).SAR: Deletion of the conserved N-terminal sequence (APAHR) reduced its antimicrobial activity, suggesting that APAHR is essential for its antimicrobial activity.MOA: Electron microscopy showed that alarin caused bacterial membrane blebbing.  Updated 11/2013; 6/2023.
Literature Information.Author: Wada A, Wong PF, Hojo H, Hasegawa M, Ichinose A, Llanes R, Kubo Y, Senba M, Ichinose Y.2013
Literature Information.Title: Alarin but not its alternative-splicing form, GALP (Galanin-like peptide) has antimicrobial activity.
